Geoprofiling resources

Michael Stevens

2020-11-23

GP_resources.Rmd

This page is for documenting any additional resources on geographic profiling.

Papers

Below are a collection of open-access papers on geographic profiling.

In ecology:

  • S. C. Faulkner et al. (2016) Using geographic profiling to compare the value of sightings vs trap data in a biological invasion
  • S. C. Faulkner et al. (2018) A spatial approach to combatting wildlife crime
  • Heald et al. (2019) Understanding the origins of the ring‐necked parakeet in the UK

In epidemiology

  • S. C. Le Comber et al. (2011) Geographic profiling as a novel spatial tool for targeting infectious disease control
  • Verity et al. (2014) Spatial targeting of infectious disease control: identifying multiple, unknown sources
  • Smith et al. (2015) Spatial Targeting for Bovine Tuberculosis Control: Can the Locations of Infected Cattle Be Used to Find Infected Badgers?

In criminology

  • Rossmo et al. (2014) Geographic profiling in Nazi Berlin: fact and fiction

Novel applications

  • Stevens et al. (2020) Investigating Sherlock Holmes: Using Geographic Profiling to Analyze the Novels of Arthur Conan Doyle

Blogs

  • Faulkner 2014 Geographic Profiling – a novel tool for locating tarsier sleeping sites
  • Faulkner and Stevens 2018 Geographic Profiling: Murder, maths, malaria and mammals
  • Romanach, Faulkner and Stevens 2019 Targeting wildlife crime interventions through geographic profiling

Spatial data and analysis

  • Robin Lovelace's Geocomputation with R

References

Faulkner, Sally C., Michael C. A. Stevens, Stephanie S. Romañach, Peter A. Lindsey, and Steven C. Le Comber. 2018. “A spatial approach to combatting wildlife crime.” Conservation Biology, 1–24.

Faulkner, Sally C., Robert Verity, David Roberts, Sugoto S. Roy, Peter A. Robertson, Mark D. Stevenson, and Steven C. Le Comber. 2016. “Using geographic profiling to compare the value of sightings vs trap data in a biological invasion.” Diversity and Distributions 23 (1): 104–12.

Heald, O. J.N., C. Fraticelli, S. E. Cox, Michael C. A. Stevens, S. C. Faulkner, T. M. Blackburn, and S. C. Le Comber. 2019. “Understanding the origins of the ring-necked parakeet in the UK.” Journal of Zoology, 1–11. doi:10.1111/jzo.12753.

Le Comber, Steven C, D. Kim Rossmo, Ali N Hassan, Douglas O Fuller, and John C Beier. 2011. “Geographic profiling as a novel spatial tool for targeting infectious disease control.” International Journal of Health Geographics 10 (35): 1–8.

Rossmo, D. Kim, Heike Lutermann, Mark D. Stevenson, and Steven C. Le Comber. 2014. “Geographic Profiling in Nazi Berlin: fact and fiction.” Geospatial Intelligence Review 12 (1): 44–57.

Smith, Catherine M., Sara H. Downs, Andy Mitchell, Andrew C. Hayward, Hannah Fry, and Steven C.Le Comber. 2015. “Spatial targeting for bovine tuberculosis control: Can the locations of infected cattle be used to find infected badgers?” PLoS ONE 10 (11): 1–14.

Stevens, Michael C. A., Gillian Ray, Sally C. Faulkner, and Steven C. Le Comber. 2020. “Investigating Sherlock Holmes: Using Geographic Profiling to analyse the novels of Arthur Conan Doyle.” The Professional Geographer. Routledge, 1–9. doi:10.1080/00330124.2020.1758575.

Verity, Robert, Mark D. Stevenson, D. Kim Rossmo, Richard A. Nichols, and Steven C. Le Comber. 2014. “Spatial targeting of infectious disease control: Identifying multiple, unknown sources.” Methods in Ecology and Evolution 5 (7): 647–55.

Contents

Developed by Bob Verity, Michael Stevens, Sally Faulkner, Steven Le Comber.
